Prompt: My husband’s uncle has great financial means however spends extremely little money on entertainment. He showed up unannounced for years often at supper hour and whenever he liked. After his girlfriend broke up with him his intrusions worsened. We repeatedly asked him to call before he came, but he would show up anyway and say “If you are busy I just go.” If we say we are busy he argues. Visits are often and prolonged. Finally, after waking us up one morning I firmly told him that he was asked to call and repeatedly violates our request. His first response was “You don’t like me.” I am also sick with Lupus and when this first big argument came I was caring for several children. He didn’t come unannounced nor even when invited for about 6 months and then out of the blue he started again. Then came the argument followed by absence then another 6 months all would start again. This cycle has been going on for about 5 years now. My husband and I explained why we needed him to call and he nodded his head as though he understood. After these talks I made sure to invite him over so that he would know he would be able to visit. His response is usually the same. “I may come, not sure what I am doing yet.” That ends up tying up our night as we don’t know if he is coming or not. If we invite others to play cards we may not be able to if he just shows up. Hubby feels guilty telling him that we are not up for company. It is badly straining our marriage as I can’t even rely on having a peaceful night. Hubby is stressed because he doesn’t want him doing it either but would put up with it if I didn’t complain. He also is extremely rude to us and other guests. He says and does mean things when he perceives an injustice towards him. Everything mean thing he does (which is often) seems to be calculated to send a message. The last 7 out of 8 invites we gave he caused issues. A pharmacist friend of mine told me to read “Controlling People” and I was shocked at how much scenarios in the book resembled this relative. How can I help my husband not feel guilty about insisting his uncle respect boundaries? My husband tries, then his uncles manipulates him and my husband yells at me as to why he can’t come over when he wants. (From Canada)
Response:
Distortion Present: Y
Cognitive Distortion: Mind Reading 

(Note: The anecdote describes the speaker's perception that her husband's uncle is intentionally trying to manipulate and upset them, without any direct evidence or confirmation from the uncle himself.)
Response_testing:
Distortion: Labeling

The patient statement labels her husband's uncle as having a specific behavior or trait ("intrusions worsened", "visits are often and prolonged", "repeatedly violates our request"), which is not necessarily an accurate description of his character. The statement also implies that the uncle has a fixed personality or behavior pattern, stating that he "always" shows up unannounced and causes problems, without considering other possible factors or nuances. This labeling creates a simplistic and overly broad view of the uncle's behavior, which may not be entirely fair or accurate.

Prompt: I’m 63-year-old male. I was abused physically and emotionally from a very young age by my father. He often whipped me with a thin pigskin belt as hard as he could while he screamed at me. When I cried he would whip me until I stopped crying. I remember the feeling of imploding when I had to do this. My mother tried to make him stop but he would lock us in the bathroom while the beating took place. I can still hear my mother screaming from the other side of the door for him to stop. When he didn’t whip me he called me names and told me I would never amount to anything. If I cried when he taunted me he would say they were “crocodile tears and didn’t mean anything.” My father died when I was 11 and as much as anything I felt relief.

Distortion Present: Y
Cognitive Distortion: Overgeneralization 

(Note: The anecdote describes a traumatic childhood experience, but the response is focused on identifying a cognitive distortion rather than addressing the trauma itself. In this case, the distortion appears to be overgeneralization because the individual's father made statements about their future potential and worth, which were likely intended to belittle and control them. However, the individual has taken these statements as absolute truths, implying that they will never amount to anything, rather than considering them as a product of their abusive upbringing.)
Response_testing:
Distortion: Overgeneralization

The patient statement presents a specific instance of physical and emotional abuse from their father, but makes sweeping conclusions about the impact it had on them. For example, they mention that if they cried when taunted by their father, he would call those tears "crocodile tears" and imply that they didn't mean anything. This is an overgeneralization because it takes a specific instance of emotional abuse and assumes it was a defining characteristic of their father's behavior towards them. In reality, there may have been other times when their father treated them differently or showed them kindness. The patient's statement implies that this one incident is representative of the entirety of their relationship with their father, which is not necessarily true.
